summary: Reading between the lines
title: Reading between the lines
description: “Everyone knows what I’m from – what I am. I was never stupid enough to think a lady would want me.” Arya Stark hears she is to be betrothed to bastard-turned-Baratheon-heir and isn’t happy about it. Gendry thinks he knows why. (He doesn’t).

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: Arya thinking about Sansa (post AGoT)
title: Arya thinking about Sansa (post AGoT)
body:
“She wished the Rush would rise and wash the whole city away, Flea Bottom and the Red Keep and the Great Sept and everything, and everyone too, especially Prince Joffrey and his mother. But she knew it wouldn’t, and anyhow Sansa was still in the city and would wash away too. When she remembered that, Arya decided to wish for Winterfell instead.” - Arya I, ACoK 

“Arya sipped at her tankard cautiously, between spoonfuls of pie still warm from the oven. Her father sometimes let them have a cup of beer, she remembered. Sansa used to make a face at the taste and say that wine was ever so much finer, but Arya had liked it well enough. It made her sad to think of Sansa and her father. “ - Arya II, ACoK

“ Bugs weren’t so bad when you got used to them. Worms were worse, but still not as bad as the pain in your belly after days without food. Finding bugs was easy, all you had to do was kick over a rock. Arya had eaten a bug once when she was little, just to make Sansa screech, so she hadn’t been afraid to eat another. Weasel wasn’t either, but Hot Pie retched up the beetle he tried to swallow, and Lommy and Gendry wouldn’t even try.” - Arya V, ACoK

“Arya looked down at her ragged clothes and bare feet, all cracked and callused. She saw the dirt under her nails, the scabs on her elbows, the scratches on her hands. Septa Mordane wouldn’t even know me, I bet. Sansa might, but she’d pretend not to.” - Arya V, ACoK

“Three black dogs raced across his faded yellow surcoat, and his face looked as hard as if it had been cut from stone. Suddenly Arya knew where she had seen those dogs before. The night of the tourney at King’s Landing, all the knights had hung their shields outside their pavilions. “That one belongs to the Hound’s brother,” Sansa had confided when they passed the black dogs on the yellow field. “He’s even bigger than Hodor, you’ll see. They call him the Mountain That Rides.” - Arya V, ACoK

“Arya had not known her brother was so near. Riverrun was much closer than Winterfell, though she was not certain where it lay in relation to Harrenhal. I could find out somehow, I know I could, if only I could get away. When she thought of seeing Robb’s face again Arya had to bite her lip. And I want to see Jon too, and Bran and Rickon, and Mother. Even Sansa … I’ll kiss her and beg her pardons like a proper lady, she’ll like that.” - Arya VII, ACoK

“His mustache was so bushy that it covered his mouth, and the clasp that held his cloak was a silver-and-sapphire trident. He belonged to Lord Tywin, but the fierce, bearded young man who liked to walk the battlements alone in a black cloak patterned with white suns had been taken by some hedge knight who meant to get rich off him. Sansa would have known who he was, and the fat one too, but Arya had never taken much interest in titles and sigils. Whenever Septa Mordane had gone on about the history of this house and that house, she was inclined to drift and dream and wonder when the lesson would be done.” - Arya VII, ACoK

“She bit her lip, groping for another name. Lommy had called her Lumpyhead, Sansa used Horseface, and her father’s men once dubbed her Arya Underfoot, but she did not think any of those were the sort of name he wanted.” - Arya IX, ACoK

“But there is no pack,” she whispered to the weirwood. Bran and Rickon were dead, the Lannisters had Sansa, Jon had gone to the Wall. “I’m not even me now, I’m Nan.” - Arya X, ACoK

“So the singer played for her, so soft and sad that Arya only heard snatches of the words, though the tune was half-familiar. Sansa would know it, I bet. Her sister had known all the songs, and she could even play a little, and sing so sweetly. All I could ever do was shout the words.” - Arya IV, ASoS

“Lady Catelyn always wanted her to be like Sansa, to sing and dance and sew and mind her courtesies. Just thinking of it made Arya try to comb her hair with her fingers, but it was all tangles and mats, and all she did was tear some out. “I ruined that gown that Lady Smallwood gave me, and I don’t sew so good.” She chewed her lip. “I don’t sew very well, I mean. Septa Mordane used to say I had a blacksmith’s hands.” - Arya VII, ASoS

“Sansa would have sighed and shed a tear for true love, but Arya just thought it was stupid. She couldn’t say that to Ned, though, not about his own aunt. "Did someone break it?” - Arya VIII, ASoS

“But that was just stupid, like something Sansa might dream. Hot Pie and Gendry had left her just as soon as they could, and Lord Beric and the outlaws only wanted to ransom her, just like the Hound. None of them wanted her around. They were never my pack, not even Hot Pie and Gendry. I was stupid to think so, just a stupid little girl, and no wolf at all.” - Arya XII, ASoS

“I know this inn. There hadn’t been a gibbet outside the door when she had slept here with her sister Sansa under the watchful eye of Septa Mordane, though. "We don’t want to go in,” Arya decided suddenly, “there might be ghosts.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“That’s stupid, Arya thought. Sansa only knows songs, not spells, and she’d never marry the Imp.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“Arya sipped her wine so they could not see her mouth. She didn’t understand what Polliver was talking about. Sansa has no other sister. Sandor Clegane laughed aloud.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“It made her feel queer to leave out Polliver and the Tickler. And Joffrey too. She was glad he was dead, but she wished she could have been there to see him die, or maybe kill him herself. Polliver said that Sansa killed him, and the Imp. Could that be true? The Imp was a Lannister, and Sansa … I wish I could change into a wolf and grow wings and fly away.If Sansa was gone too, there were no more Starks but her.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“He was a giant as tall as a mountain, and whenever Braavos stood in danger he would wake with fire in his eyes, his rocky limbs grinding and groaning as he waded out into the sea to smash the enemies. "The Braavosi feed him on the juicy pink flesh of little highborn girls,” Nan would end, and Sansa would give a stupid squeak. But Maester Luwin said the Titan was only a statue, and Old Nan’s stories were only stories.” - Arya I, AFfC

“One serving man was very old, his back bent like a bow. The second was red-faced, with hair growing from his ears. She took them both for mutes until she heard them praying. The acolytes were younger. The eldest was her father’s age; the other two could not have been much older than Sansa, who had been her sister. The acolytes wore black and white too, but their robes had no cowls, and were black on the left side and white on the right.” - Arya II, AFfC

“No one,“ she would answer, she who had been Arya of House Stark, Arya Underfoot, Arya Horseface. She had been Arry and Weasel too, and Squab and Salty, Nan the cupbearer, a grey mouse, a sheep, the ghost of Harrenhal … but not for true, not in her heart of hearts. In there she was Arya of Winterfell, the daughter of Lord Eddard Stark and Lady Catelyn, who had once had brothers named Robb and Bran and Rickon, a sister named Sansa, a direwolf called Nymeria, a half brother named Jon Snow. In there she was someone … but that was not the answer that he wanted.” - Arya II, AFfC

“Winterfell, she might have said. I smell snow and smoke and pine needles. I smell the stables. I smell Hodor laughing, and Jon and Robb battling in the yard, and Sansa singing about some stupid lady fair. I smell the crypts where the stone kings sit, I smell hot bread baking, I smell the godswood. I smell my wolf, I smell her fur, almost as if she were still beside me. "I don’t smell anything,” she said, to see what he would say.” - Arya II, AFfC

“She stood on the end of the dock, pale and goosefleshed and shivering in the fog. In her hand, Needle seemed to whisper to her. Stick them with the pointy end, it said, and, don’t tell Sansa! Mikken’s mark was on the blade. It’s just a sword. If she needed a sword, there were a hundred under the temple. Needle was too small to be a proper sword, it was hardly more than a toy.” - Arya II, AFfC

“Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa. Needle was Winterfell’s grey walls, and the laughter of its people. Needle was the summer snows, Old Nan’s stories, the heart tree with its red leaves and scary face, the warm earthy smell of the glass gardens, the sound of the north wind rattling the shutters of her room. Needle was Jon Snow’s smile. He used to mess my hair and call me “little sister,” she remembered, and suddenly there were tears in her eyes.” - Arya II, AFfC

“Bring me the face,“ said the kindly man. The waif made no answer, but she could hear her slippers whispering over the stone floor. To the girl he said, "Drink this,” and pressed a cup into her hand. She drank it down at once. It was very tart, like biting into a lemon. A thousand years ago, she had known a girl who loved lemon cakes. No, that was not me, that was only Arya.” - The Ugly Little Girl, ADwD

Needle was Jon Snow’s smile. He used to mess my hair and call me “little sister,” she remembered, and suddenly there were tears in her eyes.” - Arya II, AFfC

“Bring me the face,“ said the kindly man. The waif made no answer, but she could hear her slippers whispering over the stone floor. To the girl he said, "Drink this,” and pressed a cup into her hand. She drank it down at once. It was very tart, like biting into a lemon. A thousand years ago, she had known a girl who loved lemon cakes. No, that was not me, that was only Arya.” - The Ugly Little Girl, ADwD
trail.content:
“She wished the Rush would rise and wash the whole city away, Flea Bottom and the Red Keep and the Great Sept and everything, and everyone too, especially Prince Joffrey and his mother. But she knew it wouldn’t, and anyhow Sansa was still in the city and would wash away too. When she remembered that, Arya decided to wish for Winterfell instead.” - Arya I, ACoK 

“Arya sipped at her tankard cautiously, between spoonfuls of pie still warm from the oven. Her father sometimes let them have a cup of beer, she remembered. Sansa used to make a face at the taste and say that wine was ever so much finer, but Arya had liked it well enough. It made her sad to think of Sansa and her father. “ - Arya II, ACoK

“ Bugs weren’t so bad when you got used to them. Worms were worse, but still not as bad as the pain in your belly after days without food. Finding bugs was easy, all you had to do was kick over a rock. Arya had eaten a bug once when she was little, just to make Sansa screech, so she hadn’t been afraid to eat another. Weasel wasn’t either, but Hot Pie retched up the beetle he tried to swallow, and Lommy and Gendry wouldn’t even try.” - Arya V, ACoK

“Arya looked down at her ragged clothes and bare feet, all cracked and callused. She saw the dirt under her nails, the scabs on her elbows, the scratches on her hands. Septa Mordane wouldn’t even know me, I bet. Sansa might, but she’d pretend not to.” - Arya V, ACoK

“Three black dogs raced across his faded yellow surcoat, and his face looked as hard as if it had been cut from stone. Suddenly Arya knew where she had seen those dogs before. The night of the tourney at King’s Landing, all the knights had hung their shields outside their pavilions. “That one belongs to the Hound’s brother,” Sansa had confided when they passed the black dogs on the yellow field. “He’s even bigger than Hodor, you’ll see. They call him the Mountain That Rides.” - Arya V, ACoK

“Arya had not known her brother was so near. Riverrun was much closer than Winterfell, though she was not certain where it lay in relation to Harrenhal. I could find out somehow, I know I could, if only I could get away. When she thought of seeing Robb’s face again Arya had to bite her lip. And I want to see Jon too, and Bran and Rickon, and Mother. Even Sansa … I’ll kiss her and beg her pardons like a proper lady, she’ll like that.” - Arya VII, ACoK

“His mustache was so bushy that it covered his mouth, and the clasp that held his cloak was a silver-and-sapphire trident. He belonged to Lord Tywin, but the fierce, bearded young man who liked to walk the battlements alone in a black cloak patterned with white suns had been taken by some hedge knight who meant to get rich off him. Sansa would have known who he was, and the fat one too, but Arya had never taken much interest in titles and sigils. Whenever Septa Mordane had gone on about the history of this house and that house, she was inclined to drift and dream and wonder when the lesson would be done.” - Arya VII, ACoK

“She bit her lip, groping for another name. Lommy had called her Lumpyhead, Sansa used Horseface, and her father’s men once dubbed her Arya Underfoot, but she did not think any of those were the sort of name he wanted.” - Arya IX, ACoK

“But there is no pack,” she whispered to the weirwood. Bran and Rickon were dead, the Lannisters had Sansa, Jon had gone to the Wall. “I’m not even me now, I’m Nan.” - Arya X, ACoK

“So the singer played for her, so soft and sad that Arya only heard snatches of the words, though the tune was half-familiar. Sansa would know it, I bet. Her sister had known all the songs, and she could even play a little, and sing so sweetly. All I could ever do was shout the words.” - Arya IV, ASoS

“Lady Catelyn always wanted her to be like Sansa, to sing and dance and sew and mind her courtesies. Just thinking of it made Arya try to comb her hair with her fingers, but it was all tangles and mats, and all she did was tear some out. “I ruined that gown that Lady Smallwood gave me, and I don’t sew so good.” She chewed her lip. “I don’t sew very well, I mean. Septa Mordane used to say I had a blacksmith’s hands.” - Arya VII, ASoS

“Sansa would have sighed and shed a tear for true love, but Arya just thought it was stupid. She couldn’t say that to Ned, though, not about his own aunt. "Did someone break it?” - Arya VIII, ASoS

“But that was just stupid, like something Sansa might dream. Hot Pie and Gendry had left her just as soon as they could, and Lord Beric and the outlaws only wanted to ransom her, just like the Hound. None of them wanted her around. They were never my pack, not even Hot Pie and Gendry. I was stupid to think so, just a stupid little girl, and no wolf at all.” - Arya XII, ASoS

“I know this inn. There hadn’t been a gibbet outside the door when she had slept here with her sister Sansa under the watchful eye of Septa Mordane, though. "We don’t want to go in,” Arya decided suddenly, “there might be ghosts.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“That’s stupid, Arya thought. Sansa only knows songs, not spells, and she’d never marry the Imp.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“Arya sipped her wine so they could not see her mouth. She didn’t understand what Polliver was talking about. Sansa has no other sister. Sandor Clegane laughed aloud.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“It made her feel queer to leave out Polliver and the Tickler. And Joffrey too. She was glad he was dead, but she wished she could have been there to see him die, or maybe kill him herself. Polliver said that Sansa killed him, and the Imp. Could that be true? The Imp was a Lannister, and Sansa … I wish I could change into a wolf and grow wings and fly away.If Sansa was gone too, there were no more Starks but her.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“He was a giant as tall as a mountain, and whenever Braavos stood in danger he would wake with fire in his eyes, his rocky limbs grinding and groaning as he waded out into the sea to smash the enemies. "The Braavosi feed him on the juicy pink flesh of little highborn girls,” Nan would end, and Sansa would give a stupid squeak. But Maester Luwin said the Titan was only a statue, and Old Nan’s stories were only stories.” - Arya I, AFfC

“One serving man was very old, his back bent like a bow. The second was red-faced, with hair growing from his ears. She took them both for mutes until she heard them praying. The acolytes were younger. The eldest was her father’s age; the other two could not have been much older than Sansa, who had been her sister. The acolytes wore black and white too, but their robes had no cowls, and were black on the left side and white on the right.” - Arya II, AFfC

“No one,“ she would answer, she who had been Arya of House Stark, Arya Underfoot, Arya Horseface. She had been Arry and Weasel too, and Squab and Salty, Nan the cupbearer, a grey mouse, a sheep, the ghost of Harrenhal … but not for true, not in her heart of hearts. In there she was Arya of Winterfell, the daughter of Lord Eddard Stark and Lady Catelyn, who had once had brothers named Robb and Bran and Rickon, a sister named Sansa, a direwolf called Nymeria, a half brother named Jon Snow. In there she was someone … but that was not the answer that he wanted.” - Arya II, AFfC

“Winterfell, she might have said. I smell snow and smoke and pine needles. I smell the stables. I smell Hodor laughing, and Jon and Robb battling in the yard, and Sansa singing about some stupid lady fair. I smell the crypts where the stone kings sit, I smell hot bread baking, I smell the godswood. I smell my wolf, I smell her fur, almost as if she were still beside me. "I don’t smell anything,” she said, to see what he would say.” - Arya II, AFfC

“She stood on the end of the dock, pale and goosefleshed and shivering in the fog. In her hand, Needle seemed to whisper to her. Stick them with the pointy end, it said, and, don’t tell Sansa! Mikken’s mark was on the blade. It’s just a sword. If she needed a sword, there were a hundred under the temple. Needle was too small to be a proper sword, it was hardly more than a toy.” - Arya II, AFfC

“Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa. Needle was Winterfell’s grey walls, and the laughter of its people. Needle was the summer snows, Old Nan’s stories, the heart tree with its red leaves and scary face, the warm earthy smell of the glass gardens, the sound of the north wind rattling the shutters of her room. Needle was Jon Snow’s smile. He used to mess my hair and call me “little sister,” she remembered, and suddenly there were tears in her eyes.” - Arya II, AFfC

“Bring me the face,“ said the kindly man. The waif made no answer, but she could hear her slippers whispering over the stone floor. To the girl he said, "Drink this,” and pressed a cup into her hand. She drank it down at once. It was very tart, like biting into a lemon. A thousand years ago, she had known a girl who loved lemon cakes. No, that was not me, that was only Arya.” - The Ugly Little Girl, ADwD

summary: Revenge is a dish best served cold for an impatient, yet patient person
title: Revenge is a dish best served cold for an impatient, yet patient person
body:
Revenge is a dish best served cold for an impatient, yet patient person. #tuesdaythoughts

In life, I have had to be patient. Not much came fast or even on a timely manner to me. So, I learned to bide my time for things. The funny thing is I actually have no patience at all. I love instant gratification. But then again who doesn’t? One can be patient but appreciate a few things at a faster pace.  It’s like how my love of good rum doesn’t preclude me from drinking some run-of-the mill…

View On WordPress

blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

summary: GRRM’s original outline
title: GRRM’s original outline
body:
I have never really understood the argument that since GRRM originally planned for a Jon-Arya romantic relationship and a Jon-Arya-Tyrion love triangle, he has now replaced Arya with Sansa and that’s how we get Jonsa. Let’s get a few things straight here:

1.  THE STARK SISTERS ARE NOT INTERCHANGEABLE

2.  GRRM is still sticking to the story and ending he came up with in the early nineties. Jon and Arya still have a very, very close relationship as in the most recent book where Jon ends up dying to save Arya. Jon has almost no relationship with Sansa in the books and they are very indifferent and distant siblings who rarely think of each other and whose stories/plots have nothing to do with each other.

3. Sansa still betrays her family as per the original outline and Tyrion is not in love with her. Tyrion loved Shae while he was married to Sansa.

4. There is foreshadowing in the books for both Jon/Arya and Jon/Dany. Some of the most heartfelt love in the books is between Jon and Arya – what do you know of my heart, priestess? What do you know of my sister? Needle was Jon Snow’s smile. And between Jon and Dany the foreshadowing of - A blue flower grew from a chink in a wall of ice, and filled the air with sweetness.

5. Seeing as how Tyrion had a strange look on his face when Jon went into Dany’s room, it’s possible that we are actually getting some version of a Jon – Dany – Tyrion love triangle on the show next season and possibly in the books as well.

6. When GRRM originally intended for Jon and Arya to fall in love, it was a passion that TORMENTS them both because they dearly loved each other as siblings and that love was now turning into something else. GRRM is all about forbidden love. Jon’s oaths as a brother of the NW are also a big deal as he is sworn to celibacy. In the books, Jon finally breaks his oaths for Arya and chooses love over duty.

7. In the outline, Tyrion burns down Winterfell and Jon and Tyrion fight over Arya. In the books, Ramsay burns down Winterfell and Jon and Ramsay fight over fake Arya.

8. Jon constantly compares the women he is attracted to with Arya in the books. Ygritte and Val signify the tough, take no prisoners, pro-active women that Jon falls for. Dany would fit right in there as well – lonely, lovely and lethal. As recent as book 5, Jon espouses a dislike for girls like Sansa - A warrior princess, he decided, not some willowy creature who sits up in a tower, brushing her hair and waiting for some knight to rescue her.

9. The show putting Sansa in the North is often used to justify Jonsa. On the contrary, Sansa in the North had nothing to do with Jonsa and everything to do with David and Dan finding Sansa’s book plot too boring to adapt to TV and wanting to give Sophie Turner something meaty to do. As Benioff states :

And it’s because of Turner’s strength, Benioff continued, that it made sense to give Sansa a dramatic storyline this season and to use Ramsay’s engagement for that very purpose. In fact, the showrunners first thought about putting Sansa and Ramsay together back when they were writing season 2. “We really wanted Sansa to play a major part this season,” Benioff said. “If we were going to stay absolutely faithful to the book, it was going to be very hard to do that. There was a subplot we loved from the books, but it used a character that’s not in the show.” 

http://ew.com/article/2015/04/26/game-thrones-sansa-ramsay-interview/

So basically David and Dan wanted Sophie Turner/ Sansa to play a major role on the show, unlike in the books, and therefore put her in Winterfell instead of Jeyne Poole.Sansa’s story on the show will be different to her book one.

 So there it is. Please stop using the original outline to justify Jonsa. If we actually take the original outline into consideration then it does not bode well for Sansa at all. As per the outline Sansa is most likely doomed and is going to end the series dead. GRRM has always maintained that he knew the ending way back in the early nineties. It is possible he is going for Jon/Arya. Or he is intending for Jon/Dany. Either way one thing he is definitely not doing is Jon/Sansa considering how very little these characters have to do with each other in the books despite growing up as siblings.

As per the outline Sansa is most likely doomed and is going to end the series dead. GRRM has always maintained that he knew the ending way back in the early nineties. It is possible he is going for Jon/Arya. Or he is intending for Jon/Dany. Either way one thing he is definitely not doing is Jon/Sansa considering how very little these characters have to do with each other in the books despite growing up as siblings.

trail.content_raw:
I have never really understood the argument that since GRRM originally planned for a Jon-Arya romantic relationship and a Jon-Arya-Tyrion love triangle, he has now replaced Arya with Sansa and that’s how we get Jonsa. Let’s get a few things straight here:

1.  THE STARK SISTERS ARE NOT INTERCHANGEABLE

2.  GRRM is still sticking to the story and ending he came up with in the early nineties. Jon and Arya still have a very, very close relationship as in the most recent book where Jon ends up dying to save Arya. Jon has almost no relationship with Sansa in the books and they are very indifferent and distant siblings who rarely think of each other and whose stories/plots have nothing to do with each other.

3. Sansa still betrays her family as per the original outline and Tyrion is not in love with her. Tyrion loved Shae while he was married to Sansa.

4. There is foreshadowing in the books for both Jon/Arya and Jon/Dany. Some of the most heartfelt love in the books is between Jon and Arya – what do you know of my heart, priestess? What do you know of my sister? Needle was Jon Snow’s smile. And between Jon and Dany the foreshadowing of - A blue flower grew from a chink in a wall of ice, and filled the air with sweetness.

5. Seeing as how Tyrion had a strange look on his face when Jon went into Dany’s room, it’s possible that we are actually getting some version of a Jon – Dany – Tyrion love triangle on the show next season and possibly in the books as well.

6. When GRRM originally intended for Jon and Arya to fall in love, it was a passion that TORMENTS them both because they dearly loved each other as siblings and that love was now turning into something else. GRRM is all about forbidden love. Jon’s oaths as a brother of the NW are also a big deal as he is sworn to celibacy. In the books, Jon finally breaks his oaths for Arya and chooses love over duty.

7. In the outline, Tyrion burns down Winterfell and Jon and Tyrion fight over Arya. In the books, Ramsay burns down Winterfell and Jon and Ramsay fight over fake Arya.

8. Jon constantly compares the women he is attracted to with Arya in the books. Ygritte and Val signify the tough, take no prisoners, pro-active women that Jon falls for. Dany would fit right in there as well – lonely, lovely and lethal. As recent as book 5, Jon espouses a dislike for girls like Sansa - A warrior princess, he decided, not some willowy creature who sits up in a tower, brushing her hair and waiting for some knight to rescue her.

9. The show putting Sansa in the North is often used to justify Jonsa. On the contrary, Sansa in the North had nothing to do with Jonsa and everything to do with David and Dan finding Sansa’s book plot too boring to adapt to TV and wanting to give Sophie Turner something meaty to do. As Benioff states :

And it’s because of Turner’s strength, Benioff continued, that it made sense to give Sansa a dramatic storyline this season and to use Ramsay’s engagement for that very purpose. In fact, the showrunners first thought about putting Sansa and Ramsay together back when they were writing season 2. “We really wanted Sansa to play a major part this season,” Benioff said. “If we were going to stay absolutely faithful to the book, it was going to be very hard to do that. There was a subplot we loved from the books, but it used a character that’s not in the show.” 

http://ew.com/article/2015/04/26/game-thrones-sansa-ramsay-interview/

Either way one thing he is definitely not doing is Jon/Sansa considering how very little these characters have to do with each other in the books despite growing up as siblings.

description:
I decided to start writing an Arya/Gendry AU… I posted it on AO3, but if you haven’t seen it yet… check out Chapter 1 :)

Summary: What would happen if Cersei Lannister and her children were banished from Westeros once Ned Stark discovered they were bore of incest and not Robert Baratheon’s legitimate heirs? How would the story change? How would Arya and Gendry meet under these different circumstances?

This AU takes place 5 years after the banishment of Cersei, Jamie, and their children. It mainly focuses on Arya and Gendry and how their relationship would evolve had they met differently.

summary: Do you think that Arya isn’t connected with blue roses at all? I mean, George confirmed she will get her moonblood (also called...
question: Do you think that Arya isn’t connected with blue roses at all? I mean, George confirmed she will get her moonblood (also called flowering) in TWOW, probably when winter comes. I can see a connection here. What do you think?
answer:
Hi Anon!

I don’t see a connection between Arya and blue roses. I don’t see any connection between her flowering and a specific flower, least of all blue roses. Arya’s chapters don’t mention anything at all about blue roses, not a single mention.

The only characters who are connected in the text to blue roses are Lyanna, the Stark daughter who Bael the Bard took, and Jon (by his connection to Lyanna in Dany’s vision in the House of the Undying).

Arya does have a lot of similarities to Lyanna. There is the physical resemblance, the similar speech (both call people “stupid”) and the pragmatism. But Arya is not Lyanna. I wouldn’t want her to be, and I don’t want her to share Lyanna’s fate. I don’t think she has or will have a connection to blue roses and tbh I don’t want her to have that connection, Lyanna’s connection to the blue roses is part of the tragedy, a sad connection because of the way her story ended, and I would not wish that on another character, especially one I love.

body: Seriously any so called “parallels” between Sansa and Lyanna is weak as hell. Some situational similarities don’t equate to the very intentional parallels GRRM wrote between Arya and Lyanna for plot purposes. Stop taking from Arya just to give to Sansa. The show does this enough.
